line: One-Pager® Response to Reading Due the First Day of School in September
label: paragraph

line: Directions:
label: paragraph

line: Follow the prompt below.
label: paragraph

line: Your One-Pager should be done on a plain white paper 8-1/2 x 11” on
label: paragraph

line: side only, with your name clearly in evidence on the front side of the
label: paragraph

line: paper.
label: paragraph

line: What is a One-Pager?
label: heading

line: “ How do I know what I think until I see what I say?”
label: paragraph

line: Forster
label: paragraph

line: “Only connect.” –E.M. Forster
label: paragraph

line: A one pager is a single-page response to your reading. It is a way of
label: paragraph

line: making your pattern of your unique understanding. It is a way to be
label: paragraph

line: creative and experimental. It is a way to respond imaginatively and
label: paragraph

line: honestly. It is a way to be brief and compressed.
label: paragraph

line: The purpose of a one-pager is to own what you are reading. We learn
label: paragraph

line: best when we can create our own patterns.
label: paragraph

line: A one-pager connects the verbal and the visual; it connects the ideas in
label: paragraph

line: what you read to your thoughts. It connects words and images. The one-
label: paragraph

line: pager becomes a metaphor for the reading you have done.
label: paragraph

line: When you do a one-pager, do any or all of these:
label: paragraph

line: a. Pull out a quotation or two, using them to explore one of your own
label: paragraph

line: ideas, and write them on the page (perhaps using a different
label: paragraph

line: colored pen).
label: paragraph

line: b. Use visual images, either drawn or cut from magazines, to create a
label: paragraph

line: visual focus.
label: paragraph

line: c. Cluster around a dominant impression, feeling or thought you have
label: paragraph

line: while reading.
label: paragraph

line: d. Make a personal statement about what you have read.
label: paragraph

line: e. Ask a question or two and answer it (them).
label: paragraph

line: f. Create the one-pager so that your audience will understand
label: paragraph

line: something about the reading from what you do.
label: paragraph

line: g. Feel free to use colored pens or pencils.
label: paragraph

line: What not to do:
label: paragraph

line: a. Don’t merely summarize.
label: paragraph

line: b. Don’t be restricted by the lines on the paper. Use unlined paper.
label: paragraph

line: c. Don’t think a half a page will do—make it rich with quotes and
label: paragraph

line: images.
label: paragraph

line: Grading: full credit depends on completeness (and imagination counts,
label: paragraph

line: too.)
label: paragraph
